title.narrative: UN System-Wide Evaluation for Collective UN Accountability and Learning on COVID-19

description.narrative: The project is to support a coherent System-Wide Evaluation of COVID- for gathering evaluative evidence on (a) how the UN is contributing collectively to reversing the challenges brought by COVID-19 in the first year of the decade of action for SDGs, and (b) providing credible evaluative evidence on progress, innovation, good practices and lessons learned. The project support system wide management response and action to the evaluation recommendations. The design of the evaluation leverages the COVID -19 Response and Recovery fund to learn lessons and report progress of UN contribution as a whole. The approach of the proposals is in line with the UN development reform and the Funding Compact.

title.narrative: Global Thematic Fund for Health Covid-19

description.narrative:
Support to Covid-19 through Unicefs global thematic fund for health
Covid is having a serious impact on children and households - causing reduced use of health services, less access to school and increased household poverty and malnutrition. The impacts on children and women are significant. UNICEF has a multi pronged approach to supporting countries and communities to implement covid responses. Unicef is involved form global to local - and across key sectors.

title.narrative: Mali, Unicef thematic fund for health Covid-19

description.narrative: Earmarked contribution to Covid-19 health response in Mali - negotiated at country level between embassy and UNICEF. Mali has suffered a coup - is in the midst of civil strife and massive climate degradation. On top of thes epressures the covid 19 response is presenting major challenges. UNICEF works across sectors to support women and children. Norway supports health and nutrition as well as education via seperate agreements.

title.narrative: CIC 2020 - Effective cooperation across the HDP nexus in the context of COVID-19

description.narrative: This project will expand on CIC's work supporting the UN and its partners to prevent and address protracted crises by engaging more effectively across the HDP nexus in fragile and at-risk countries. The project will aim to generate practical ideas to strengthen HDP linkages in a range of contexts and to operationalize conflict prevention more effectively. The project's activities will be in East Africa, West Africa, Sahel, Middle East/North Africa, New York, Geneva, Oslo, and TBD.

title.narrative: Pre-project Phase to Developing a Digital Approach to Ensure Inclusive Education Delivery

description.narrative: The aim of this initiative is to leverage new and readily available digital technologies to enhance outreach and quality of education services in ASEAN CLMV countries to offset the negative implication of social distancing and non-access to physical education services as result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Project has two phases: a Pre-Project with the objective to specify the structure (including potential methodology and partners), scope and deliverables of the project; and Phase 2 (the Main Project) where the concept is developed and implemented in accordance with the specification of the Pre-Project.

title.narrative: Support to Migrants and local communities in SRB, MAK and MNE

description.narrative:
Support to Migrants and Local Communities in Montengro, North Macedonia and Serbia. The project intends to provide comprehensive, well-planned and tailor-made subgranting support to a number of communities in Serbia, Montenegro and North Macedonia. In addition, it will include extensive and relevant capacity-building efforts as well as the evidence-based advocacy initiatives in the area of forced migration.
Due to Covid-19 pandemics, subgranting support was extended to benefit all vulnerable groups.

title.narrative: Support to UN Emergency Appeal for Response to COVID-19 and its impact

description.narrative:
This UN coordinated emergency appeal calls for $316.4 million to respond to the immediate COVID-19 public health response and the most urgent needs generated by the secondary consequences caused by the COVID-19 outbreak for the most vulnerable Ugandans. The appeal prioritizes the most urgent interventions to be carried out in Uganda in the next six months (April to September 2020) in support of the Government-led response to COVID-19. Complementing the Government of Uganda and the Ministry of Health’s response, the appeal focuses on: 1) the immediate public health response to COVID-19, and 2) response to the secondary impacts of the pandemic on vulnerable Ugandans, including children, the elderly, women, people living with disabilities, people living with HIV, refugees, migrants, and those displaced by natural disasters.
The appeal targets at risk communities across Uganda under five core themes: 1) Life-Saving Health Services, including the immediate COVID-19 public health response; 2) Food Security, Livelihoods and Nutrition; 3) Social Protection and Life-Saving Essential Services; 4) Refugees and Displacement; and 5) Immediate Economic Support & Digital Innovation. Under each theme, the Appeal presents two sets of time-bound interventions, as follows: 1. The most urgently required immediate interventions for the public health emergency and impacts from COVID-19 in next eight weeks are prioritized and highlighted; 2. These are placed alongside priority interventions that will tackle long-term public health interventions aimed at containment of COVID-19 and address the impacts of the containment measures over the next six months. The appeal targets 12.8 million people in need.

title.narrative: Supporting preparedness, mitigation and response to the primary and secondary impacts of COVID-19 on IDP and vulnerable populations in Yemen

description.narrative: Given the context of COVID-19, combined with the already dire humanitarian needs in Yemen, our approach aims to prevent, mitigate and respond to COVID-19: in the immediate/short-term by providing life-saving assistance through targeted and coordinated activities in WASH, protection, and cash to IDP and vulnerable populations. The programme will provide an integrated, package across two governorates; Hodeidah and Taizz.

reporting-org.narrative: The Leprosy Mission Nepal

title.narrative: Leveraging leprosy infrastructure to strengthen the COVID19 response

description.narrative: The Project will increase the preparedness of Anandaban Hospital to deliver critical COVID-19 care to patients experiencing COVID-19 complications including vulnerable individuals including people affected by leprosy and disabilities and to protect the most vulnerable and health workers from infection. The project will do this by training all staff in COVID-19 response including testing, treating, and managing cases; opening an isolation ward aimed to treat critical patients using ventilators and respirators; providing counselling sessions for both staff and patients struggling with their experience of COVID-19; sharing awareness-raising messages about how to keep safe during the pandemic; and by distributing food and sanitation packages amongst households in the local community.

recipient-country.narrative: Leveraging leprosy infrastructure to strengthen the COVID -19 response

sector.narrative: The Project will increase the preparedness of Anandaban Hospital to deliver critical COVID-19 care to patients experiencing COVID-19 complications including vulnerable individuals including people affected by leprosy and disabilities and to protect the most vulnerable and health workers from infection. The project will do this by training all staff in COVID-19 response including testing, treating, and managing cases; opening an isolation ward aimed to treat critical patients using ventilators and respirators; providing counselling sessions for both staff and patients struggling with their experience of COVID-19; sharing awareness-raising messages about how to keep safe during the pandemic; and by distributing food and sanitation packages amongst households in the local community.

tag.narrative: The Project will increase the preparedness of Anandaban Hospital to deliver critical COVID-19 care to patients experiencing COVID-19 complications including vulnerable individuals including people affected by leprosy and disabilities and to protect the most vulnerable and health workers from infection. The project will do this by training all staff in COVID-19 response including testing, treating, and managing cases; opening an isolation ward aimed to treat critical patients using ventilators and respirators; providing counselling sessions for both staff and patients struggling with their experience of COVID-19; sharing awareness-raising messages about how to keep safe during the pandemic; and by distributing food and sanitation packages amongst households in the local community.

humanitarian-scope.narrative: The Project will increase the preparedness of Anandaban Hospital to deliver critical COVID-19 care to patients experiencing COVID-19 complications including vulnerable individuals including people affected by leprosy and disabilities and to protect the most vulnerable and health workers from infection. The project will do this by training all staff in COVID-19 response including testing, treating, and managing cases; opening an isolation ward aimed to treat critical patients using ventilators and respirators; providing counselling sessions for both staff and patients struggling with their experience of COVID-19; sharing awareness-raising messages about how to keep safe during the pandemic; and by distributing food and sanitation packages amongst households in the local community.

description.narrative: To assist Solomon Islands Government to develop a sustainable niche tourism industry in Western Province, including supporting an industry response to and recovery from the impacts of COVID-19. title.narrative: MF1-01 Inclusive Education in Papua New Guinea

description.narrative: Leveraging gains from a previous NZ Aid Programme funded activity (PF 3-413 Papua New Guinea - Education and Rehabilitation for children with disabilities) cbm (Christian Blind Mission NZ) will provide inclusive education and health services for people with disabilities in PNG, supporting over 30,000 direct beneficiaries. The activity will include COVID-19 awareness raising and information, as well as equal access to health services for the most vulnerable groups in remote areas in PNG.

title.narrative: MF1-04 Planem Gud Famili Blong Yumi sexual and reproductive health and rights Phase Two in Vanuatu

description.narrative: Family Planning NZ (FPNZ) will implement phase two of the activity Planem Gud Famili Blong Yumi sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) in Vanuatu. Phase two will be funded through Manaaki and will build on the success of the Partnerships for International Development (PFID) activity PF10-588 Planem Gud Famili Blong Yumi SRHR in Vanuatu. FPNZ is also supporting their in-country partner, Vanuatu Family Health Association (VFHA), to assist the Vanuatu MoH in its COVID-19 programme.

title.narrative: Occupied Palestinian Territories :Explosive Ordnance Risk Education

description.narrative: The Activity will support efforts to reduce the risk of harm from explosive hazards in the West Bank of the Occupied Palestinian Territories through (1) enabling the Palestinian Mine Action Center to deliver Explosive Ordnance risk education (EORE) in the West Bank, (2) training trainers to continue providing EORE, and (3) institutional strengthening of the PMAC. WHO messaging on hand washing and social distancing will be incorporated to minimise risk of spreading COVID during or after training.

title.narrative: Covid-19 - 2020 Tonga Immediate Health Systems Preparedness Activity

description.narrative: Support to Tonga for preparedness and response to a potential Covid-19 outbreak in the region. Initial fund from Cabinet Paper approved 16/03/2020. Tonga requested support for its strategic preparedness and response plan for COVID-19, costed at a total NZ$3.2 million. This includes medical equipment and supplies, the renovation of a community health centre, PPE, transport and lab supplies. New Zealand will provide a NZD1 million untagged grant.

description.narrative: This Activity has been created to purchase and preposition Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and medical supplies in New Zealand to enable a rapid response in the event of a significant outbreak of Covid-19 in the Pacific.

title.narrative: Gavi COVID-19 Support

description.narrative: Support for Gavi's Third Replenishment (2021-25) to support the provision of vaccines to the developing world. This support recognises the important role Gavi will play in ensuring equitable distribution of a future COVID-19 vaccine and the possibiltiy that traditional vaccines will be in greater demand as a mitigation measure for COVID-19.

title.narrative: Covid-19 Pacific Small to Medium Enterprise Finance Facility

description.narrative: This activity will support Pacific small to medium enterprises to manage the economic impact of COVID-19 through facilitating access to emergency liquidity support, renegotiation of existing loans and long-term adaptation investment. This activity is expected to be delivered through existing multi-country activity Business Link Pacific in partnership with local financial institutions.

title.narrative: COVID 19 Response and Recovery Multi-Partner Trust Fund Africa

description.narrative: The United Nations (UN) COVID-19 Response and Recovery Multi-Partner Trust Fund (COVID-19 MPTF) is a UN inter-agency finance mechanism launched by the UN Secretary-General to support low and middle income programme countries in overcoming the health and development crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Fund’s assistance targets those most vulnerable to economic hardship and social disruption. A contribution will be ear-marked for sub-Sahara Africa.

title.narrative: COVID 19 PPE and C19 medical supplies

description.narrative: Solomon Islands is currently under a State of Public Emergnecy and have strict quarantine measures in place. Its stocklpile of PPE is running low and additional testing equipment is becomming a necissity amidst nationals returning to Solomon Islands. This Activity will facilitate the procurement and supply of the Covid-19 medical supplies for Solomon Islands.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Improve Cook Islands' Health Capability: PCR laboratory and ICU

description.narrative:
This Activity is strengthening the Cook Islands' laboratory and critical care capability, and vaccine cold storage capacity, to support readiness for a COVID-19/other infectious disease outbreak, quarantine-free travel and vaccine rollout. It is establishing:
  • local 'gold standard' polymerase chain reaction testing capability (lab alterations, machine, equipment, consumables, training); 
  • improved critical care  (equipment, training); and
  • sufficient vaccine cold storage capacity.

title.narrative: Covid-19 - Suppporting the World Bank COVID project that will establish a Public Health Laboratory

description.narrative: This activity provides funding towards the World Bank COVID-19 Emergency Response Project, designed in partnership with the Ministrty of Health in Samoa. Specifically, New Zealand will fund sub-component 2.2: Establishment of a Public Health Laboratory for human and animal health. This sub-component falls under Component 2: Systems Strengthening for Pandemic Preparedness and Response; in turn it is one of the three project components supporting Samoa's response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

reporting-org.narrative: New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

title.narrative: COVID-19: Maori/Pacific Tourism Partnership - Aho Rua / Va'a tele

description.narrative: A long-term Maori / Pacific tourism partnership, led by New Zealand Maori Tourism. Maori tourism operators are world class in indigenous business operations, and developing visitor experiences based on cultural interpretation and interactions. Mutually beneficial reciprocal Maori/Pacific B2B relationships are formed, indigenous business expertise is shared. Pacific destination and product differentiation improves post-COVID returns, moving Pacific visitor experiences up the value chain.

reporting-org.narrative: New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

title.narrative: Repatriation Services for Stranded Scholars

description.narrative: Centralising the repatriation of scholars stranded in NZ as a result of COVID 19-related border closures, to cover scholars who have completed their qualifications but are unable to repatriate within the standard 14 days. Such scholars will be placed in a pool for the service provider to manage. Management will consist of scholar needs analysis (dependents, etc), identifying commercial and (particularly) non-commercial repatriation options, travel management and reporting to MFAT.
